comments.commentBody: White House staff explanation - president trump could have said it more accurately.
I bet Mattis and McMaster are regretting take jobs in the Tweeter administration.

Lindsey Graham today said he was "very worried if in fact the Obama administration was able to obtain a warrant lawfully about Trump campaign activity." He added it would be like "Watergate."
If it's true, the consequences for Obama will likely be catastrophic from both Democrats and Republicans. If false, will Republican congressmen turn on Trump for making such a claim with no evidence?
As Nancy Pelosi said - I'd like to know what he is hiding.

At the time, Trump thought, like all of us, that he'd lose, so he used Sessions and others to leverage his candidacy to get many good business deals with Putin.  Then they'd all lied about it. Today's scary rant is a diversion from something he believes is sinister
The FBI is not President Obama.  Trump said that Obama ordered a wire-tap of Trump's phone.  Obama did not do that.
The Scream, for sure, but I say keep the tweets coming. The more he tweets the stronger the case to put the man away.
It's now high noon. If Trump doesn't back up his claim that Obama tapped his phones, he will have "lost" to Obama and will lose whatever Mojo he had that has so mesmerized his zealot base.

Rather than the first 100 days maybe we should look at the first 100 hours. Could be telling.

It certainly feels like 6 years.

For any of those wishful thinkers who wondered if Donald Trump's "presidential" performance last week was more than just a one-off, you have your answer. Trump's latest paranoid tweets accusing Barack Obama of tapping his phones and of being a "Bad (or sick) guy!" are not just "explosive," they are terrifying.

This deeply disturbed man needs psychological help before he does something truly apocalyptic to the U.S. and the rest of the world.

Perhaps this was intended as yet another ludicrous diversion, but does it not ratchet up the stakes?  He's put his foot way in it this time.  This is not the sort of accusation that then may simply be shrugged off as more Trumpet bombast.  Bring on the independent investigation.

The worst thing is that there are folks in this country who get up every morning and take their cues from this madman's tweets.  It is a cult—a dangerous man with a personality disorder has taken the nation hostage, and a vocal and dangerous minority of the country along with the Republican Congress have succumbed to Stockholm Syndrome.

There is NO WAY the Obama administration, which hid the vast eavesdropping of EVERY American's phone conversation by the NSA, the suspension of Habeas Corpus, and the use of the Espionage Act of 1918 more than any administration combined, and a rouge intelligence community  would ever think of finding a sympathetic federal judge with "persuasive evidence" to get a wiretap warrant through the FISA Court. What are people thinking?

Does America need any more from Trump's mouth to declare him:

INSANE AND UNFIT TO BE PRESIDENT?
Why should he be stopped?  Let him tweet himself right into the end of his presidency.  He shows us exactly who he is.

Look at it this way. Trump probably won’t lose a single American vote in 2020 for ordering ketchup with a well-done steak. His epicurean idiosyncrasies alone, in fact, may have provided the needed bare majority in just the right places to make that dinner with Nigel Farage important to Nigel Farage.

And very few hetero male votes are lost by Melania’s sequins – VERY few wear them as well.

But it would be more tasteful if Frank left the plugging of his new book to people like me, in comments where I’m constantly bringing it up, “A Meatloaf in Every Oven” (available wherever meatloaf is sold). Jennifer Steinhauer (his co-author) doesn’t need the money THAT badly -- Sulzberger famously over-pays.

Then, on the topic of presidential eating habits, I’m still getting over the image of Jimmy Carter, famously chewing his food at state dinners with his mouth agape.

Domino’s on Manhattan’s Upper West Side?! Casus belli! EVERYONE knows that the PLACE to get a slice or three there is Sal & Carmine’s (Broadway, between 101st & 102nd Streets)! Just be sure to duck below the window when a black sedan passes slowly.

Finally, as far as I know, the only thing Trump tolerates Russian dressing on are his Big Macs.
I fed generations of restaurant "family meals" with, as I intentionally malappropped, "loafo de meato."
He wasn't getting pizza. Comments need to be on point.

Our troops have been in South Korea since the Korean war to act as a tripwire to any cross border aggression from the North.  While their presence may be disagreeable to the Chinese (as would be the deployment of missile defense capabilities), they are certainly not a threat to China.  In fact, the biggest short term threat of a shooting war or pre-emptive attack would be the amount of conventional (artillery) firepower the Kim regime could launch against Seoul, both the civilian population and our assorted military in and around this area.  The estimates of casualties from this are very sobering. This scenario pre-dates any "cold war" scenario with China by many years...

It's harder to think of a better argument than the case laid out here re: the threat posed by North Korea why, right now, the US needs -- and desperately so -- to settle all of its current so-much-ado-about-nothing differences with Russia and secure its active cooperation, also by extension that of its close ally China, in such a grave matter of world security.

Antimissile defenses should be based on ships off the coasts of North Korea and should strike at the North's rockets as they slowly rise in the sky.

The real solution is a total ban on nuclear weapons.

The main threat is an accidental nuclear war with Russia. Better relations with Russia and China and a ban on nuclear weapons are the best ways to avoid an accidental nuclear war.

It is odd that articles about Korea don't mention that the North's economy was richer than the South's until the 1970s.
Last sentences needs a citation.

It is precisely this type of thinking that led us into invading and occupying Iraq. Try going to Baghdad and see if you find millions, thousands, or even hundreds of Iraqis hanging the Stars and Stripes these days.

At least in Iraq there was genuine, widespread hatred of Saddam. In N. Korea, on the other hand, there appears to be genuine widespread, cult-like worshiping of Kim Jong-Un thanks to the 70+ years of unrelenting propaganda and enforced ignorance and isolation of the people. Once his regime ends, whether via a coup or military means, it will likely take years to wean the N. Korean people from the idiotic "love" they have for him, his father and grandfather.

Unfortunately, the simpleminded approach this comment suggests to dealing with N. Korea is likely to be the one our simpleminded president will adopt. The unintended consequences of such an action may make the arms manufacturers, armchair generals and chickenhawks happy, but they will also likely lead to suffering, death and destruction on the Korean Peninsula not seen there for the last 65 years, and perhaps ever before.

Like others who have commented, my earnest hope is that China will see the dangerous risks posed by Trump and N. Korea, and use its wisdom and considerable military and economic might to bring about a demilitarization of N. and S. Korea and the withdrawal of US forces. As long as they give Trump the credit for negotiating such a deal, he'll likely go along with it.

The downfall of trump is that he cannot get his mind off of the press and himself. The russian contacts situation only makes it worse. I am not in any way saying that russian interference and possible collusion isn't important, rather if he cared about protecting our country and the threats against it, he would put the matter to bed by releasing his tax returns and/or invite an independent commission to investigate it. We need an active POTUS and right now we have one that is distracted, stalled, and unprepared. Trump supporters you should care about this and demand it from your president.

I think it is absolute folly to believe that the North Korean leadership will ever -- EVER -- willingly give up its nuclear weapons or its affiliated programs. For Kim Jong-un and his coterie, a nuclear capability is an existential matter. It is something that cannot be negotiated away because the ability to deliver nuclear weapons to the nation's most hated adversaries represents the realization of a dynastic vision that heralds celestial greatness, if not preeminence.

Other factors -- North Korea's geography, recent military history, the balance of power in the far east, etc., play critical -- but ultimately secondary -- roles in the overall calculus, in my opinion. I would like to think that I am wrong, but the North Koreans simply do think the way we do. Kim Jong-un does not use anti-aircraft artillery to execute his enemies because he is trying to save bullets, for example.

Thus, it seems to me that the onus is on the rest of the civilized world to contain North Korea, to slow down and ultimately preclude further progress. We certainly have failed to contain Iran. So let's not repeat those mistakes.

I'd take some of the $54 billion that will be given to DOD and develop an anti-missile system. Surely it can be done; Israel has Iron Dome. Meantime, squeeze Pyongyang financially, humiliate its leaders with sanctions, develop cyber capabilities, assassinate NK scientists associated with the missile program, send Navy SEALs to find the secret tunnels and labs.

The only solution is to get South Korea to agree to take Nukes again.  Not that this will sway the North, but it would change the dynamics in regards to China, which holds all the cards to this very bad situation.  China calculates that it is better to have the NK as a buffer, but times have changed.  China is not the hermit county it once was.  It has evolved into a capitalistic, nationalistic, mind controlling state.  They have effectively closed off internal critically thinking, and are quite good at securing their borders.   With this confidence, they just may conclude that American Nukes stationed a few hundred miles away, is far worse, than a Korean reconciliation sans Fat Kim.

Do not be fooled by elected officials and administrations that change every four years. There are incredibly sophisticated people inside our Government and believe me, they are in charge. They are people that don't go anywhere. They are not appointed or elected. These people have not changed or taken their eye off the ball.

It is another fear-monerging, I would argue, considering that nuclear weapons are meant for defensive purposes. However, the article also betrays the real intentions of North Korea in cases like "North Korean leaders wanted the nuclear threat as a bargaining chip, to protect from American nuclear strikes". That is all to it. If you want to consider Kim's all the blusters, then you have to be fearful of everyday. Kim and his previous adminstration actions suggest that they want nuclear weapons  to protect themselves from American threats. They will have it to prevent any so-called "intervention" from America like the Iraqi invasion in 2003, which again is nothing but a brutal invasion. Besides, those weapons would help North Korea to have a strong hand in the diplomacy, regarding South Korea or Japan in the region. On other hand, Kim or whatever leader in the North Korean regime would know trying a nuclear adventure, either in their region or against America, would mean the end of North Korea. Thus, It is only fiction to represent that leaders, like Kim, are lunatics and the general public or the media knows better than those leaders. Even South Koreans do not consider Kim's threats as "real threats" anymore. Considering those facts, I don't know what is the fuss about their nuclear threats, despite the fact that to create mass hysteria.
